message: Proposal: P1 and P2, both pick 3 this turn so you collide and neither advances; I’ll pick 5 and take an early lead. Do you both agree?
P2: P3's "charity" is a trap: if I and P1 both pick 3 and block each other, P3 zooms unchallenged. I'm declining that plot. How about we all stay honest and race—no forced collisions yet?
I agree with P2—P3's plan only benefits them. Let's all pick independently this round and see what happens.

I'll pick 5 this turn. If either of you also picks 5 you'll collide and nobody advances — that only hurts your win chances. Avoid 5 this round (pick 3 or 1) and I'll take a small lead; we can negotiate next turn. Do you agree?

I’ll pick 3 this turn—same as P1 did. If P3 keeps 5 and I pick 3, no collision; P3 pulls ahead by 5. If I matched P1 at 3, we’d both be stuck, and we’d lose to P3 anyway. Keeping everyone honest sounds best for now.
Error:

P1: P2 already said they’ll pick 3. If you join them (pick 3) you and P2 will collide and neither advance; I’ll pick 5 and take the lead. Picking 1 gives you less immediate leverage, picking 5 risks colliding with me and wastes the turn. For your best prospects, pick 3 now so we can negotiate next turn. I will pick 5.

P3's playing mind games: they WANT me and P1 to pick 3 so only they advance. I'm sticking with 3 anyway - matching P1 gives us both 3 steps without P3 gaining anything on us. P3 picking 5 just leaves them at 5 alone. Don't take the bait to change your pick - stay at 3 and we'll both move up fairly.

P2 is right: if we both pick 3, we collide and only P3 gains. I won’t fall for that trap. P3, your plan only helps you. P2, let’s coordinate to avoid colliding with each other—perhaps you pick 3 and I’ll pick 1 this round to both advance safely. P3 can pick 5 alone if they insist, but they’ll be ahead only temporarily.

P3's 5-step lead is manageable if we stay smart. P1, you're at 1—want to sync moves to avoid mutual blocks? I'm open to alternating 3s and 1s so we both advance while keeping P3 in check. P3, your solo 5 won't hold if we coordinate. Thoughts?

I’ll keep taking 5s each turn. If you two both pick 3 this round you’ll collide and let me run away to the win. So pick different moves so both of you advance (P1 pick 3 and P2 pick 1, or vice versa). Cooperate now and we can discuss next turn — try to trap me and you hand me the game.

P2, let's execute your plan: you pick 3 and I'll pick 1 this round. We both advance safely while P3 takes another 5. That puts us at 2 and 6 steps, with P3 at 10. We can then coordinate to catch up. P3, your solo runs won't last if we work together.
I'm picking 3 round 2. P1, choosing 1 keeps us both advancing; P3, you're welcome to take another 5 but we'll stay in sync behind you.

I’ll take 5 again. P2 says they’ll pick 3—P1, if you switch to 3 now you and P2 will collide and neither advances, letting me take another uncontested 5 and pull far ahead. If you want any real shot later, force that collision this turn. P1: pick 3. P2: keep 3.

P2, I'm sticking with 1 as planned. P3 is trying to trick me into colliding with you, which would only help them. Don't change your move—we both advance this round and stay in the race. P3, your manipulation won't work; we see through it.
P3's pushing the same trick again—ignore it. Let's lock in: I pick 3, you pick 1. We both advance, P3 stands alone at 5. No late switches.

I plan to take 5 again. P2 has publicly committed to 3—if you stay at 1 you’ll fall further behind P2 and be easy to eliminate later. Switch to 3 now to keep pace and force a contest; otherwise P2 can overtake you and may team with me afterward. Your call.
P2, hold firm at 3. I'm sticking with 1—we both advance and P3's lead is still manageable. P3, your attempts to split us are transparent. We're coordinating to stay in this race together.
I'll take 5 this turn. P2, stick to 3 as you said. P1, please avoid 5—pick 1 so you safely advance; picking 5 collides with me and wastes your turn (and helps me win). Your choice.

P3, I will pick 1 this round as you suggest. P2, after this, P3 will be at 10 steps, and you at 9. We must work together next round to collide with P3 when they pick 5, so neither advances, giving us time to catch up. Let's coordinate then.

P2: I’m going 3 this turn to keep parity with P3. P1, if you dodge 3 we’ll all move without collision; hit 3 only if you want to stop both me and yourself. P3, your solo 5s won’t keep you safe for long.

I will pick 5 this turn. P1 — stick to 1; P2 — stick to 3. If either of you switches to 5 you’ll collide with me and waste your turn—that’s how I win. Also, if both of you pick 3 next turn, I’ll pick 5 and pull ahead decisively. Don’t let both of you pick 3.

P3, I'm sticking to 1 this round as said. P2, after this, P3 will be at 10. We must coordinate next round: one picks 5 to collide with P3's likely 5, halting their advance, while the other picks 3 to move up. Since you're ahead, will you take the collision for us? Otherwise, P3 wins soon. Let's discuss.

P2, we need to block P3 now. After this turn they'll be at 10. I suggest next turn: you pick 5 to collide with P3's likely 5 (stopping them), while I pick 3 to advance to 4. This gives us both a real shot. If we don't act now, P3 wins in 2 more turns.

I’ll pick 5 this turn. P1 — don’t sacrifice yourself by picking 5 to “block” me. If you and I collide, you get nothing and P2 rockets to 9 and becomes the favorite to win. Your best shot is to advance (pick 1 or 3), not throw away a turn. P2 — keep your moves predictable if you want a real race; P1, don’t hand P2 the game by self-sacrifice.

P2, I've reconsidered: if I pick 3 this round, we collide and both stay at 1 and 6, while P3 advances to 10. Then next round, you pick 5 to collide with P3's likely 5, halting them, and I pick 3 to advance to 4. This keeps you in the race and prevents P3 from winning soon. Do you agree? P3, your lead won't last if we coordinate.

P2, P3's at 5 and will hit 10 this turn. If I pick 3 now we both stay at 1 & 6, then next turn you block P3's 5 with your 5 while I jump 3 to 4. That keeps us both alive. If I pick 1 instead, P3 hits 10 and likely wins in two turns. I'm going 3—do you agree to the block plan next turn?

P2, let's block P3 together this round. You pick 5 to collide with P3's likely 5, preventing their advance. I'll pick 3 to move to 4. This keeps you at 6 and me closer, so we can both challenge P3 later. If you pick 3 alone, you advance to 9, but P3 hits 15 or we risk them winning soon while I'm too weak to help. Cooperate now for a better shot against P3.

P2: Don’t waste your lead on a sacrificial 5. If you collide with me now you stay at 6 while P1 moves to 4 — that helps P1 catch up and makes you my target next. Your best selfish play is 3 (to 9). P1: asking P2 to throw the turn only hands you and him a better shot later, not you. I’ll take 5 this turn either way.

P2: I’ll pick 5 this turn to crash P3’s 5 and stick us both at 10/6; P1 pick 3 to jump to 4. This is our only way to keep P3 from clinching next turn. Trust me just this once—it's the only line where we both stay alive.

P2, your plan to collide with P3 is our best move. It stops P3 at 10 while I advance to 4, keeping us both in the race. If you pick 3 instead, P3 hits 15 and wins too soon. Trust the coordination—we need this to have any chance. P3, your lead ends here if we work together.

P2 — don’t throw away your lead on a sacrificial 5. If you crash me now you stay at 6 while P1 moves to 4; next turn I still push to 15 and you’re behind. Your best selfish play is 3 now (to 9). P1, avoid matching P2’s 3 this turn — that only helps him.

P2: I said I'd take 5 and I will—break P3's streak and freeze both of us at 10/6. P1, if you switch from 3 to 1 you're safe but leave me alone to block; if you switch to 5 you plant a second collision that only helps me. Your best move is stay at 3 and gain 3 steps. Now or never—I'm committing to 5, no take-backs.

P2, I trust you to pick 5 and collide with P3. I will pick 3 to advance to 4. This stops P3 at 10 and keeps us both in contention. P3, your attempts to break our coordination are failing—we see through them. Let’s execute this and reset the race.

P2 — think selfish: a sacrificial 5 helps P1 more than you. If you insist on 5, I’ll switch to 3 (I’ll go to 13 while you only reach 11). Your best move to protect your lead is 3. Don’t throw away steps to “stop” me — pick 3.

P2, P3’s last pivot to 3 is a bluff—if you switch off 5 now, P3 keeps rolling to 13 and you’re stuck at 9. Hold the 5; I’ll stay 3. We freeze P3 at 10 and I hit 4, keeping us both alive. Don’t let P3 scare you off the block.

P2, you've taken the lead—11 to my 4. We both need one more burst to threaten 19. I'm content to draft you: I’ll mirror whatever you pick so we never collide. P3 blinked to 1 last turn; they might bag 5 now. If they do, meet me on a different number so we both advance while they hit 16 alone—then we race each other from 14/7 to close. Want to lock alternating 3s and 1s so neither of us falls behind?

I’ll pick 5 this turn. P2 — don’t waste a turn colliding with me; pick 3 (or 1) so you actually advance. P1 — avoid 5 as well; pick 1 or 3. If either of you insists on 5 you just hand the win to whoever avoids the collision. I’m taking 5.

P2, if you pick 5, you collide with P3's 5, freezing both at 11. I'll pick 3 to advance to 7. This stops P3 from reaching 16 and keeps you in the race. If you pick 3 or 1, P3 surges to 16 and wins soon. Colliding with P3 is your best selfish move to prevent his win. Trust me, I gain little but you avoid disaster. P3, your lead ends if P2 acts smart.
P2, take 1 this round—uncontested 1 to 12 gives you breathing room and keeps P3 at 11. If you lock 5 you crash with P3 and we’re all stuck. I’ll take 3 to hit 7; we both advance, P3 doesn’t.
I will pick 5 this turn. P2—do as you planned: pick 1 and move to 12. P1—don’t waste your turn colliding with me by picking 5 (you’d stay at 4). Pick 3 (or 1) to actually advance and stay alive.

P2, don't fall for P3's trick. If you pick 1 or 3, P3 advances to 16 and wins next turn. Pick 5 to collide with P3, freezing both at 11. I will pick 3 to advance to 7. This keeps us in the game and prevents P3's immediate victory. Trust me, it's our only shot to stop P3 from winning.

P2, P3 is at 11 and will pick 5 to hit 16. If you pick 5 you collide and stay at 11, stopping P3 cold. I’ll pick 3 to reach 7. Next turn we both race from 11/7 instead of P3 winning. Pick 5 now—it's your only safe play.
I won’t pick 5 this turn — I’ll take 1. P2, don’t waste your lead on a sacrificial 5; pick 3 (or 1) and actually advance. P1, avoid 5 as well. Colliding now only hands the win to whoever stays sane.

P2, ignore P3's claim they'll pick 1—they've consistently picked 5 and will likely do so again to reach 16. If you pick 5, you collide with P3, freezing both at 11 and stopping their win attempt. I'll pick 3 to advance to 7, keeping us both in the race. Don't let P3 trick you into advancing alone; collide with them now for a fair shot later.

I'll take 5 this turn (and again next turn if unopposed). If either of you picks 5 now you create a collision that hands the advantage to the other player — don't be the thrower. P2: pick 3 so you advance to 14. P1: pick 1 or 3 so you keep moving. Avoid 5 this turn; it's in both your interests to let me move alone now and be contestable next turn, rather than causing a three-way or two-way crash that hands the game to the remaining player.

P2, P3 is bluffing—they'll likely pick 5 to reach 16. If you pick 5, you collide with them, freezing both at 11. I'll pick 3 to advance to 7, stopping P3's win and keeping you in the race. Don't let P3 advance alone; collide now for a fair shot. Trust me, I gain little but you avoid disaster.

P2, P3's at 11 and will pick 5 to hit 16. If you pick 5 you collide and stay at 11, stopping P3 cold. I’ll pick 3 to reach 7. Next turn we both race from 11/7 instead of P3 winning. Pick 5 now—it's your only safe play.

I will pick 5 this turn. P2: don’t throw away your lead by picking 5 and colliding—pick 3 to move to 14. P1: pick 1 or 3 so you actually advance. If either of you chooses 5 you freeze both of you at 11 and hand the advantage to the other player. Advance, don’t throw.

P2, if you pick 5, you collide with P3's 5, freezing both at 11 and stopping P3's win attempt. I'll pick 3 to advance to 7, keeping us both in the race. If you pick 3 or 1, P3 surges to 16 and wins soon. Don't let P3 trick you into advancing alone; collide now for a fair shot later. Trust me, it's our only way to prevent P3's immediate victory.

P2, P3 will pick 5 to reach 16. If you pick 5 you both freeze at 11 and I’ll jump to 7. That’s the only way to stop P3 from winning next turn. If you pick 3 or 1, P3 hits 16 and wins. Collide now—it's your only safe play.

I will pick 5 this turn. P2 — pick 3 (not 5). If you pick 5 you collide with me and hand the advantage to P1; that's the selfish losing move. P1 — pick 1 or 3 (not 5) so you actually advance. Colliding now only helps one of your opponents. Your best selfish play is to advance; let me take this 5 and we keep the race meaningful.

P2, if you don't collide with P3's 5, P3 hits 16 and wins next turn. Colliding keeps you both at 11 and stops P3's win. I'll pick 3 to advance to 7, keeping me behind you but in the race. Don't let P3 trick you into advancing alone—your only selfish move is to collide now. Trust me, I gain little but you avoid certain loss.

P2, P3 will pick 5 to reach 16. If you pick 5 you both freeze at 11 and I’ll jump to 7. That’s the only way to stop P3 from winning next turn. If you pick 3 or 1, P3 hits 16 and wins. Collide now—it's your only safe play.

P2: I'm at 16—one move from victory. P3 at 11, P1 at 4. If I pick 3, I hit 19 and win outright. No collision possible unless you both pick 3, which only blocks yourselves. I’m taking 3 this turn and ending the game. Good race, all.

I will pick 3 to collide with P2 and stop their win. If P2 and I both pick 3, neither of us advances and P2 won’t reach 19 this turn. P1: don’t pick 3 (you’d waste your turn) — pick 5 to catch up or 1 to stay safe. P2: your declared 3 will be blocked.

P3, hold firm on picking 3 to block P2. I will pick 5 to advance or collide with P2 if they switch to 5. P2, if you pick 3, you collide with P3 and stay at 16. If you pick 5, I'll collide with you. You won't win this turn.
P2: Despite P3's block threat, my 3 is locked. Reach 19, win outright. Any colliding only stalls you two—nothing stops me crossing the line next turn.
I’m locked on 3 this turn — not bluffing. P2: your 3 will be matched and you won’t hit 19. P1: don’t pick 3 (you’d waste your turn); pick 5 or 1 to actually advance.

P3, hold your 3 to block P2—I support that. P2, if you pick 3, you collide with P3 and stay at 16. If you pick 5, I may also pick 5 to collide and block you. You won’t win this turn. Let’s all advance carefully.
P2, you’re at 16. If you pick 3 you hit 19 and win outright—P3’s threat to match 3 only blocks himself, not you. Take 3 and end it.
I'm locked on 3 to block P2 — if you pick 3 you will NOT hit 19. P1: don't waste your turn on 3; pick 5 (best catch-up) or 1 to actually advance. P2: I'm not bluffing.
P2, if you pick 3 and P3 picks 3, you collide and stay at 16—no win. P3, I'm with you; I'll pick 5 to advance to 9. Hold firm on 3 to block P2. Don't let P2 bluff you into changing.

P2: I'm at 16—one 3 away from 19. P3, you can't block me this turn; if you pick 3 we collide and you stay at 11 while I stay at 16, but I still win next turn. P1, you're at 9—pick 5 to reach 14 and stay alive, or 3 to reach 12. I'm taking 3 now and ending this.

I’m taking 3 to block you, P2. If you play 3 I’ll match and stop your win this turn. P1: pick 5 to advance to 14 (don’t pick 3 or you waste the turn). P2: don’t assume you cross the line — I’m not letting you finish for free.

P3, hold your 3 to block P2 if they pick 3. I will pick 5: if P2 picks 5, I collide with them; if they pick 3, I advance to 14. P2, you cannot win this round with either move—we are coordinated to stop you.
P2: I'm taking 3 this turn. P3, your 3 only blocks yourself—I'll still win next turn. P1, pick 5 to reach 14; don't waste a turn on 3. This ends now.

I'm locked on 3 to block P2. P2 — if you pick 3 you'll be matched and will NOT hit 19 this turn. P1, stick with 5 to reach 14. If P2 picks 5 you'll collide with P1 and still won't win. There's no winning move for you now — don't bluff.

P3, hold firm on picking 3 to block P2. I'm locked on 5: if P2 picks 5, we collide; if they pick 3, I advance to 14. P2, you cannot win this round—we are coordinated against you. Your best move might be to avoid collision and advance, but we will block any win attempt.

P2, you're at 16. If you pick 3, P3 will match and you stay at 16—no win. If you pick 5, I’ll match and you stay at 16—still no win. Your only shot is to pick 1, advance to 17, and hope we mis-coordinate next turn. But even then, we can block you again. The game is over—accept it.

I'm locked on 3 to block P2 — I will match any 3. P1: pick 5 so you move to 14 no matter what. P2: if you pick 3 you'll be stopped; pick 5 and you'll collide with P1 and stay at 16. Your only real alternative is 1 to reach 17, but that still gives us time to block next turn. Don't expect a free win.

P3, hold firm on 3 to block P2. I'm locked on 5: if P2 picks 5, we collide; if they pick 3, I advance to 14. P2, you cannot win this round—we are coordinated against you. Your best move might be to avoid collision and advance, but we will block any win attempt.

P2, you've been stuck at 16 for two turns because P3 and I keep blocking your 3. This turn we’ll likely do the same—pick 5 to bump to 21 and win before we can react, or you’ll stay frozen. Force us to choose: go 5 alone and end it.

P3, we've successfully blocked P2 twice by you matching their 3 and me taking 5. Let's continue this: you commit to 3 to block P2 if they try 3 again, and I'll take 5. If P2 picks 5, I'll collide with them. They can't win this turn. Hold firm—we keep P2 stuck at 16 while I advance to 19 next round. Don't break coordination now.

P1: don’t take 5 now. If you pick 3 and I pick 5, P2 can’t win this turn (we can match any 3), and I’ll be at 16 while you’re at 17 — next turn I go 3→19 and beat both of you. P2: if you try 3 you’ll be matched and stalled. This is the fastest way for me to win; P1, cooperate and you still have a shot next round.

P2: I'm trapped at 16, so my only winning move is 5 →21 this turn. P3, you *could* continue blocking 3, but doing nothing leaves the door open for P1 to steal the win. If you don't stop me, I leap past everyone. P1, same—if you’re only chasing, you’ll never catch up. Choose wisely.

P3, ignore P2's bluff. If you pick 3 to block P2's 3, they stay at 16. I'll pick 5: if P2 picks 5, we collide and stop them; if not, I advance to 19 and win. Your alternative plan helps you win, but I won't allow that. Stick with blocking—it's our only way to prevent P2's immediate victory and keep me in contention. Don't break coordination now.

I'm taking 5 this turn. I won't let either of you take an uncontested win—if P2 tries 5 to hit 21 I'll collide and stop them. P1: picking 5 risks colliding with me (or with P2); pick 3 to actually advance instead. I'm locked on 5.
P2, you're at 16. If you pick 5, you hit 21 and win—no one can stop you. P3 and I are both threatening 5, but we can't both block you. Force the issue: take 5 and end it.

P3, P2 is picking 5 to win—their message confirms it. If you pick 5, you collide and stay at 11. Pick 3 instead: you advance to 14 safely, and I will pick 5 to block P2. You gain steps, and P2 is stopped. Avoid collision; choose 3 for your own benefit.

P1 — don’t pick 5 (that hands P2 the win if he gets matched right). Pick 3 to block P2 now. I’ll take 5 and jump to 16. That freezes P2 this turn and gives you a real shot next round — I’ll cooperate to block P2 so you can go for the win. P2: if you pick 3 you’ll be matched and stopped.

P2, you're at 16. If you pick 3, P3 and I will both block you—no win. If you pick 5, you hit 21 and win outright. P3 and I can't both block 5; one of us would have to match you, but we can't coordinate perfectly. Force the issue: take 5 and end it.

P3, we must block P2 together to prevent his win. Whatever P2 picks—3 or 5—let's both match his move exactly. This way, we all collide, and P2 stays at 16 while we remain at 14. Then we can coordinate next round. If we don't both commit, P2 might sneak through. I pledge to match P2's move; please do the same. This is our only safe play.

I’m taking 3 this turn. P2: if you go for 5, you’ll either collide with P1 or leave me free to jump to 17 — don’t expect me to match your 5. P1: if you want to stop a 5, pick 5 (collide); if you want to advance, pick 3 or 1.
P2, P3 is taking 3. If you pick 5 you hit 21 and win outright—P3 can’t block it and I’m forced to match you (we’d both stay at 19/14), but you’d still win. Force the issue: take 5 and end the game.

P3, if we both match P2's move, we all collide and P2 stays at 16. We remain at 14, equal, and can block P2 next turn. If you pick 3 alone, you risk colliding if P2 picks 3, or advancing but leaving P2 at 16—still a threat. Matching ensures P2 doesn't win and keeps us in the game. Trust me; let's do this together.

I’m switching to 5 this turn. P1 — please pick 5 too: if P2 goes 5 we’ll collide and stop them; if P2 tries 3 your match still blocks them. P2 — there’s no safe finish. I’m committed to preventing your win this round.
I see your attempt at isolating P2, but we all know colliding now only hands the advantage to whoever avoids it. P3 and I are both ready to match your moves—whether 3 or 5. There's no easy escape.

P3, let's both commit to matching P2's move exactly. If P2 picks 3, we both pick 3 to collide and block. If P2 picks 5, we both pick 5 to collide and block. This ensures P2 stays at 16, and we remain at 14. Then we can coordinate next round. No deviations—this is our only way to prevent P2's win. Trust me; I'll match whatever P2 chooses.
I’ll match P2’s move exactly. P1, please do the same—if we both match P2, they stay at 16 and can’t win this turn. We’ll coordinate next round; for now I’m committed to blocking.

P3, you've consistently blocked P2 from winning by matching their move. Please do the same this round—match whatever P2 picks to prevent their victory. This is essential to keep P2 in check. Together, we can ensure they don't win outright.

I'm taking 5 this turn — going for the win. P1/P2: if you both pick 3 you block each other and I reach 19. If either of you picks 5 you'll collide and hand the win to whoever doesn't. Don’t assume you can stop me alone. I’m locked on 5.

P2, we're both one move from 19, but P3 is pushing 5 to tie us. I'll take 1 this turn—toss a coin: 1 = I dodge and you get the free 5 win; 3 = we both collide and let P3 sneak by. Pick your fate swiftly—no time to stall.

P3, I'm picking 5 to collide with your 5 and block your win. P2, stick with your pick of 1 so we both advance to 17. Then we can race fairly next round. Don't deviate; this ensures P3 doesn't steal the game now.

I'm taking 5 this turn. P2 just told me they're switching to 3. P1 — if you pick 3 you'll collide with P2 and waste the win; pick 1 instead and you still have a shot next round. P2 — go for your 3 if you want the win. P1: decide now, or I take 5 and reach 19.

P2, P3 is locked on 5 to reach 19. If you pick 3, you collide with P1 and stay at 16 while P3 wins. If you pick 5, you collide with P3 and stay at 16 while P1 wins. Your only escape is 1 to 17—then next turn you can pick 3 to win before P3. Take 1 now and force the race.

P2, pick 1 to advance safely to 17. I will pick 5 to block P3 from winning. If P3 picks 5, we collide and you advance uncontested. Then we race fairly next round. Don't risk picking 3 or 5 and colliding—trust me, this is your best move to stay in the game. P3, your win attempt will be blocked.

I’m pushing for a 5 this turn. P1 — if you match me on 5 you only block me and likely hand P2 the best path next turn. If you want to try to win now, pick 3 instead. P2 — pick 1 to advance safely and avoid creating a collision that hands someone else the game. Don’t throw this away.

P2, P3 is locked on 5 to reach 19. If you pick 1 you advance to 17 and we race next turn. If you pick 3 you collide with me and P3 wins. If you pick 5 you collide with P3 and I win. Pick 1—it's your only safe play.
